questions.question: Question 1: Where does urethral stricture most commonly occur?
questions.explanation:
The most common site of urethral stricture is the bulbar urethra. A urethral stricture is a narrowing of the urethra caused by scarring, which functionally causes 
obstructive voiding dysfunction of the lower urinary tract. The most common cause of urethral stricture is trauma. It can also be iatrogenic due urethral 
catheterization and infections. These patients present with features of the hesitancy of micturition, straining to void, and poor 
urinary stream. The most common complication of urethral stricture is urinary tract infection.

questions.question: Question 2: Identify the investigation and the lesion depicted in the image given below.

options.a: Retrograde cystourethrogram with membranous urethra stricture
options.b: Retrograde cystourethrogram with penile urethral stricture
options.d: Micturating cystourethrography with prostratic urethra stricture

questions.explanation:
The given image shows retrograde cystourethrogram with findings consistent with penile urethral 
stricture. The male urethra can be visualized by retrograde urethrography (RGU) or voiding 
cystourethrogram (VCU), also known as micturating cystourethrogram (MCU). 967 
Sold by @itachibot In RGU, the urethra is visualized with the instillation of contrast into the anterior urethra (penile 
urethra and bulbar urethra). It is helpful for diagnosing anterior urethral abnormalities. The following image shows an RGU with bulbar urethral stricture: In VCU, after injecting contrast into the bladder using a Foleys catheter, the posterior urethra 
(membranous urethra and prostatic urethra) is visualized during micturition. It is helpful for 
diagnosing posterior urethral abnormalities and bladder abnormalities. It is the investigation of 
choice for vesicoureteric reflux (VUR) and posterior urethral valve.

questions.question:
Question 3: 960 
Sold by @itachibot A 40-year-old man presents to the OPD with complaints of difficulty to start urination and 
that he has to strain to maintain a proper flow. He gives a history of pelvic injury one year 
back. Investigations reveal a stricture of length 1.5 cm at the bulbar urethra. What will be the 
best management for this patient?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario with a short bulbar urethral stricture (<2cm) due to trauma, will be 
best managed by excision with end-to-end urethroplasty. It is the gold standard for the repair of 968 
Sold by @itachibot anterior urethral stricture. The management of a urethral stricture depends on the site, the length, and the cause of the 
stricture. They include: • Endoscopic urethrotomy - The stricture is released using a knife passed through a rigid 
urethroscope. • Urethroplasty - Excision of the stenosed length of the urethra and re-anastomosis is done. 
A buccal mucosa graft can be used to bridge the gap. It is considered when a stricture is due to 
trauma or recurred following endoscopic treatment. • Urethral dilation - The urethra is stretched using urethral dilators. This is a blind procedure and 
it can cause injury. Hence, it is not done frequently. • Intermittent self-dilatation - In patients with recurrent strictures who are unable to undergo 
urethroplasty, then intermittent self-dilatation with soft hydrophilic catheters is done on a daily 
basis.

questions.question:
Question 4: A man was brought to the emergency department after he fell into a manhole and injured his 
perineum. He gets an urge to micturate but is unable to urinate. On examination, blood was 
seen at the tip of the urethra, and swelling of the penis and scrotum was seen. What is the site 
of injury?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario with a history of a blow to the perineum, blood at the tip of the 
meatus, swelling of the penis and scrotum is suggestive of an injury to the bulbar urethra. Urethral injuries can be classified into: Note: Urinary bladder rupture occurs due to an injury to the suprapubic region. Extraperitoneal 
bladder rupture is more common and associated with pelvic fracture. Intraperitoneal bladder 
rupture is caused by a blow or a fall on a distended bladder. It manifests as sudden severe pain in 
the hypogastrium and syncope. Type 
Proximal urethral injury 
Distal urethral injury Bulbar urethraPenile urethra Site of injury

questions.question:
Question 5: A 20-year-old was brought to the ER after falling off his bicycle. His vitals were stable, but he 
had a bruise over the perineum and he has not passed urine yet. Blood was seen at the 
meatus and the bladder was not palpable. What will be the next step in the management of 
this patient?

options.d: Wait for bladder to fill and urge to urinate

questions.explanation:
The clinical features such as perineal bruise and blood at the urethral meatus following a fall from 
the bicycle are suggestive of a bulbar urethral injury. In this case, as the bladder is not palpable 969 
Sold by @itachibot the best option would be to wait for the bladder to fill and urge to urinate. Once the bladder is full 
the urine should be drained by a suprapubic catheter. Foleys catheter insertion should not be done in cases of suspected urethral injury, as it can 
convert a partial tear into a complete tear.

questions.question:
Question 6: A worried mother brings her 18-month-old son to OPD with complaints of repeated urinary 
tract infections. During diagnostic work-up, pelvic USG shows the following finding. What is 961 
Sold by @itachibot the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario with the USG showing the key-hole sign is suggestive of the posterior 
urethral valve (PUV). It is seen due to dilatation of the bladder and the proximal urethra. The posterior urethral valves are membranes that have a small posterior slit, which lies just distal 
to the verumontanum. They function as flap valves and are obstructive to antegrade urinary flow. The posterior urethral valve is the most common congenital cause of bladder outlet obstruction in 
males. PUV is classified into three types based on Young's classification. Diagnosis is made antenatally with ultrasound, which demonstrates bilateral hydronephrosis 
above a distended bladder. If the diagnosis is not made antenatally, then neonates typically 
present with urinary infection or uremia and renal failure. The investigation of choice for a posterior urethral valve is micturating cystourethrography 
(MCUG). Initially, the obstruction is relieved by catheterization to preserve renal function. Definitive 
treatment is by urethroscopic destruction of the valves with lifelong supportive treatment. The following VCUG shows vesicoureteric reflux due to posterior urethral valves: 970 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 7: A newborn was found to have a following anomaly of the penile urethra while being examined 
by a pediatrician. Identify the incorrect statement regarding the condition. 962 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: It is the most common congenital abnormality of the urethra
options.b: Circumcision should be done to remove the excess skin
options.c: It does not cause urinary obstruction
options.d: Ventral chordee is a common association

questions.explanation:
The image showing a newborn having a urethral meatus that opens on the underside of the penis 
is indicative of hypospadias. Circumcision should not be done in hypospadias as the foreskin will 
be used for surgical reconstruction. Hypospadias is the most common congenital abnormality of the urethra. It is characterized by the 
combination of: • A ventrally placed urethral meatus (underside of penis or perineum) • Poor development of the ventral aspect of the prepuce (resulting in hooded foreskin) • Ventral chordee (bending of the penis) 971 
Sold by @itachibot Hypospadias does not cause either obstruction or urinary tract infection and surgery is 
recommended for sexual, urinary stream, or cosmetic reasons. Note: In hypospadias, ventral chordee is seen, whereas, in epispadias, dorsal chordee is seen. The image below shows a hooded prepuce: The image below shows epispadias with bladder exstrophy:

questions.question:
Question 8: What is the appropriate age at which corrective surgery should be done for the defect shown 
in the image?
questions.explanation:
The image shows penoscrotal hypospadias. Operations for hypospadias are routinely performed 
when the patient is between 6 and 18 months of age. The infant has good tolerance to surgery by 
the age of 6 months. The child is well aware of his genitalia and will be toilet trained by the age of 
18 months. 972 
Sold by @itachibot Surgery in hypospadias is done to correct problems with the urinary stream and for cosmetic 
reasons. The main principles of surgery in hypospadias include: • Orthoplasty - Chordee correction • Urethroplasty - To reposition the urethral opening • Glanuloplasty - Reconstruction of glans • Skin cover and scrotoplasty Surgery depends on the site of the hypospadias. Tubularized incised plate (TIP) urethroplasty is 
the most commonly done procedure. It is done for distal hypospadias. Complications of hypospadias surgery include: • Urethrocutaneous fistula (most common) • Recurrence of chordee • Urethral stricture • Meatal stenosis • Infection

questions.question:
Question 9: A patient with sickle cell anemia presents to the casualty with complaints of painful erection 
of the penis for the past 5 hours. On examination, his penis is rigid. Penile blood aspiration is 
performed and it shows dark-colored blood. This patient can be managed by all of the 
following, except:
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario with a sickle cell patient having prolonged erection and dark-colored 
blood in penile aspiration is suggestive of low-flow priapism. Selective arterial embolization has 
no role in low-flow priapism. Persistent erection of penis lasting longer than 4 hours is defined as priapism. If the erection lasts 
for more than 6 hours, ischemia and necrosis can occur. Hence ischemic priapism is a 
surgical emergency. Stuttering or intermittent priapism is historically described as recurrent unwanted and painful 
erections in men with sickle cell disease (SCD). Any patient who has experienced an episode of 
ischemic priapism is also at risk for stuttering priapism. Type 
Low-flow / Ischemic priapism 
High-flow / Non-ischemic pri

en the artery and the sinusoi

questions.question: Question 10: What is the most common cause of erectile dysfunction?
questions.explanation:
The most common cause of erectile dysfunction (ED) is stress. It can also be associated with 
diabetes, hypertension, dyslipidemia, and smoking. The most common pathological cause of ED is vascular disease affecting the penile arterial blood 
flow. Evaluation of ED involves confirmation of the diagnosis by history taking, assessing the patient 
for underlying risk factors, and physical examination of the genitalia. Measurement of the blood 
pressure and assessment of the secondary sexual characteristics is also done. Biochemical assessment of the blood sugar, the serum lipid profile, and the serum testosterone is 
done in all cases. Treatment involves the use of phosphodiesterase-V inhibitors (sildenafil) with an intra-cavernosal 
injection of alprostadil. Vacuum erection devices and penile implants are reserved for resistant 
cases. The most common cause of erectile dysfunction in: • Middle-aged men: Psychological 974 
Sold by @itachibot • Older men: Organic (atherosclerosis) • Overall: Psychological

questions.question: Question 11: All of the following are indications to perform circumcision in children, except:
questions.explanation:
A tight frenulum and physiological phimosis are not indications of circumcision in children. Physiological phimosis is seen in children that are less than 6 years of age (2-6 years) due to 
natural adhesions between the glans and inner preputial skin. It rectifies on its own. Circumcision is the surgical removal of the foreskin that covers the glans penis. Indications of circumcision in children: • True phimosis (associated with a white, scarred preputial orifice, most common just before 
puberty) • Paraphimosis • On request (most common) • Balanitis xerotica obliterans (BXO) • Recurrent UTI with abnormal upper urinary tract • Recurrent balanoposthitis Indications of circumcision in adults: • Recurrent balanitis • Tight frenulum (Splitting of frenulum can occur during sexual activity) • Inability to retract the foreskin for intercourse 975 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 12: A 7-year-old boy was catheterized for a surgical procedure, and an intern noticed the 
following finding when he removed the catheter. A manual reduction was attempted and was 
not successful. What will be the next step in the management of this patient? 964 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The clinical history and the image showing swollen glans are suggestive of paraphimosis. If 
manual reduction of the skin is unsuccessful, a dorsal slit procedure should be performed. Paraphimosis is the inability to place back the retracted preputial skin. This creates a ring-like 
constriction, and the glans tend to be swollen, and edematous, with severe pain and tenderness. 
Paraphimosis is precipitated after sexual intercourse or iatrogenically after urethral 
catheterization. The first line of treatment includes manual reduction of the skin by applying lignocaine jelly. Ice 
bags and injection of a solution of hyaluronidase in normal saline may help to reduce the swelling. If this fails, an initial dorsal slit is made to relieve the edema and compression. Antibiotics and 
analgesics are also given. Circumcision is performed after 3 weeks.

questions.question: Question 13: In patients with which of the following symptoms is Nesbitt’s procedure done?

options.a: Penile deformity, painful erection and palpable penile plaques
options.b: Downward directed stream of urine with bending of penis
options.d: Popping sound during sexual intercourse, painful and flaccid penis

questions.explanation:
Penile deformity, painful erection, and palpable penile plaques are features associated with 
Peyronie's disease. Nesbitt’s procedure is the most common procedure done for this condition. Peyronie's disease is caused due to injury to tunica albuginea resulting in microhemorrhages. This 
leads to excess collagen deposition, calcification, and penile plaques. Hence, the penis 
bends towards the side of the plaque. This causes difficulty during sexual intercourse. It is also 
associated with Dupuytren's contracture. 976 
Sold by @itachibot Nesbitt's procedure corrects the deformity by plicating the opposite side of the deformity, thereby 
straightening the penis. This procedure is done once the active phase subsides as the bend 
increases during the active phase (18-24 months). Option B: Downward directed stream of urine with bending of the penis are symptoms of 
hypospadias. Option C: Persistent erection lasting longer than 4 hours is called priapism. Option D: Popping sound during sexual intercourse, painful and flaccid penis is suggestive of 
fracture of the penis. There will be bluish discoloration of the penis and scrotum due to extensive 
bruising (eggplant deformity). Management is mainly surgery for evacuation of hematoma and 
repair of corpora. The image below shows eggplant deformity in fracture of the penis: 977 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 14: Heineke-Mikulicz principle is used in which of the following procedures?
questions.explanation:
The Heineke-Mikulicz principle is used in both preputioplasty and frenuloplasty. The Heineke-Mikulicz principle involves the use of a longitudinal incision followed by a 
transverse closure, or vice-versa. In preputioplasty, it allows for the retraction of the foreskin, and 
in frenuloplasty, it allows the lengthening of the frenulum. Heineke-Mikulicz's pyloroplasty also uses the same principle. Here, a longitudinal incision is done 
through the pylorus, with extension to the duodenum and gastric antrum. This incision is then 
closed transversely. It is done for gastric outlet obstruction and along with highly selective 
vagotomy.

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following statements is false regarding carcinoma of the penis?

options.a: Balanitis xerotica obliterans is a pre-malignant condition
options.c: Jackson staging is used to stage the disease

questions.explanation:
Superficial inguinal lymphadenopathy in the context of carcinoma of the penis more often reflects 
infection rather than metastatic disease. It is usually a painless condition and the patient presents late because of embarrassment or 
misdiagnosis. They may present with: • Large fungating lesion • Foul, bloody discharge (secondary to infection) • Non-retractile prepuce • Enlarged inguinal lymph nodes (often due to infection) • Erosion of inguinal lymph nodes Jackson staging is used for the staging of penile carcinoma: • Stage I - Only glans / prepuce involved • Stage II - Tumour extending into the body of penis • Stage III - Tumour having mobile inguinal nodes • Stage IV - Tumour spreading to adjacent structures / fixed nodes Premalignant lesions of penile squamous cell carcinoma include • Bowen disease - Reddish papules in the shaft of the penis • Erythroplasia of Queyrat - Reddish papules involving glans and prepuce • Condyloma acuminatum - Usually benign, but can undergo a malignant transformation 
(Buschke–Löwenstein tumor) when associated with HPV 16, 18, 31, 33, 35, and 39 • Balanitis xerotica obliterans (BXO) - White, thickened foreskin which forms a constricting band. 
This prevents retraction and later develops into carcinoma • Leukoplakia The following image shows erythroplasia of Queyrat: 978 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 16: A 52-year-old man came to the urology OPD with complaints of a slow-growing ulcerative 
lesion in the penis for the past few months. On examination, a fungating mass in his glans 965 
Sold by @itachibot penis was seen and lymph nodes were not palpable. He was suspected to have penile 
carcinoma. Which of the following statements is false regarding the management of the 
patient?

options.a: MRI is the investigation of choice for staging
options.b: 1cm margin of normal tissue must be removed
options.c: Sentinel lymph node biopsy should be done
options.d: If stump is < 3cm, total amputation of the penis is done

questions.explanation:
In penile carcinoma, total amputation of the penis is done if the stump is < 2cm. The investigation of choice for penile carcinoma is a biopsy from the primary tumor. For staging, 
MRI is the investigation of choice. The first lymph node to be involved is the superficial inguinal lymph node and thus, the sentinel 
lymph node biopsy (SLNB) is helpful for evaluating the spread of penile cancer. The management is divided into treatment of the primary tumour and the treatment of the lymph 
nodes. The main principles of penile cancer surgery are to remove a 1cm margin of normal tissue and 
have at least a 2cm stump after surgery. Surgery is the mainstay treatment of penile cancer. Chemotherapy regime includes 5-fluorouracil 
and cisplatin. Radiotherapy can be done for inguinal lymph nodes if lymph node dissection is not 
done. 979 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following is the most important prognostic factor in patients with penile cancer?
questions.explanation:
Inguinal lymph node status is the most important prognostic indicator in penile carcinoma. The prognosis for tumors confined to the penis is good with 5-year survival rates in excess of 
80%. With nodal involvement, the 5-year survival rate falls to around 40%. 980 
Sold by @itachibot Testes and Scrotum
